posts.subject: 08ch Secure Access Package - Zeronet + Tor Browser running from a RAMdrive
posts.body:
LINK
----
https://mega.nz/#!utcjFCCJ!XX_jwMpHpRkXg2XzYwT4l5tup2uyBQresDeV_t8l7QA

ABOUT
-----
I wanted a more secure way to access 08chan on ZeroNet.  Like many others, I have some concerns about keeping a copy of the entire site on my system, and ZeroNet isn't configured as securely as it could be "out of the box".  This package was created to address these issues.  The software and all data are stored on a Ramdrive (not on your harddrive).  

Ramdrive/Ramdisk - a virtual drive that is created by setting aside part of the random-access memory to use as if it were a group of sectors; "access to a RAM disk is very fast but the data it contains is lost when the system is turned off"

By shutting down or rebooting, data stored in RAM is lost.  LOST DOES NOT MEAN UNRECOVERABLE!  There is a 2012 article where security researchers found that some systems retained data in RAM even after shutdown.  This RAM would be overwritten during memory intensive usage and during the normal course of use, but they discovered that the data wasn't truly unrecoverable (forensically speaking) until mains/wall power was removed from the system.  If you access something you shouldn't or are paranoid, shut down and pull the power from your system (30+ seconds) after using this.


WHAT'S INCLUDED
---------------
This package provides securely pre-configured copies of ZeroNet and Tor Browser.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ZeroNet
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tor_(anonymity_network)

ZeroNet is not especially secure "out of the box".  As a result, ZeroNet has been pre-configured to use Tor for all connectivity, including connections to trackers.  Numerous additional trackers were added and the 08chan site was setup as a favorite (w/1gb storage limit).  The CP board/userid has been pre-blocked.  All data for the 08chan site was removed before compressing the image (any needed data will automatically re-download upon first launch).

IMPORTANT: All encryption keys were removed from ZeroNet.  This means that each time you reboot and re-launch (re-creating the Ramdrive), the encryption keys are recreated.  While this is great for maintaining anonymity, if you wanted your userid/hash to remain the same across posts/reboots, this probably isn't the best solution for you.

Only two configuration changes were made to the Tor Browser package.  The first is that 127.0.0.1 (your local computer address) was added to the proxy exclusion settings.  This was required because ZeroNet is accessed on a 127.0.0.1 address.  The only other change is that the homepage was set to the ZeroNet Hello page (which shows the 08chan site/link under "Favorited Sites").

>>689ed806-b6d7-49c1-95b5-5f3dff82e776

You can't request 127.0.0.1 to external tor nodes/relays.  This address is not routable on the Tor network.  The top button on HelloZero does not show a warning as it does when you access outside of tor browser (with chrome etc).  The reason that ZeroNet recommends using Tor browser is because of the hardening that has already been done, things that are blocked - things which are enabled by default for your other browsers.

You can for sure make your own package out of this.  You can use imdisk to make a new .img file.  You would simply replace the ramdisk.img file in the folder with the new image you generate.  Everything else is batch scripts, so you can see what is going on and modify to suit.

I wanted something that was tor end to end, preconfigured, I wanted new certs at every launch, and I sure as hell didn't want it stored (even temporarily) on media which was friendly to forensic recovery.  

Hopefully someone else will find some use from this.  It's not obvious that ZeroNet isn't configured to use Tor out of the gate.  "normie" and paranoia friendly I guess you could say.

>>43681c64-137b-497e-8387-8d722e185e0f

Yeah, it's not very seed friendly.  

The screenshot you posted matches the settings that were changed in Tor/Zeronet + setting the homepage.

>>61b6055a-0002-4545-a071-95e11412e7f7

Yes but you can do the same in *nix!  Ramdrive software is more easily available on Linux than Windows.

Essentially:
1. Create 2gb ramdrive and make sure it's in RAM (not swap) and changes aren't persisted after reboots

2. Format

3. Install tor and zeronet on the device

4. Use dd to image it

5. Create a script to create the ramdrive and restore the dd image and another script to kill it (or just rely on a reboot)

>>5018efd2-dc81-4e35-961e-61e1a89d990b

This would make zeronet use the tor server that is bundled with tor browser instead of the tor software/server that is bundled with zeronet.  It could be beneficial resource wise, but tbh I don't mind one "Tor ID" for zeronet and a different "Tor ID" for the browser I'm using.  No way to tie what I'm doing in the browser back to what I'm using for Zeronet this way.
